The use of lumogallion as a sensitive fluorescent molecular probe for aluminium [ [7](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR7)] has revealed the unequivocal identification of particulates of Alhydrogel® and Adju-Phos® in vesicle-like structures in the cytoplasm of a relevant monocytic THP-1 cell line [ [64](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR64)]. For both adjuvant formulations those particulates internalised were of approximately 1 m in size and were found exclusively in the cell cytoplasm. As Alhydrogel® was found internalised at every concentration of the adjuvant, this demonstrated its greater cytoplasmic loading versus Adju-Phos® whereby uptake was diminished at 50 and 100 g/mL of the ABA. As such, this may infer that AH based adjuvants are more prone to migrate from the injection site [ [64](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR64)]. The release of extracellular DNA from dying cells has been found to enhance the adjuvanticity of ABAs, as DAMPs that activate the Nalp3 inflammasome [ [138](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR138), [167](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR167)]. Therefore, the reduced cellular uptake of Adju-Phos® and its enhanced cytotoxicity at the injection site in comparison to Alhydrogel® may act to mediate its adjuvanticity by an alternative cellular pathway of immunopotentiation [ [64](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR64)]. Direct fluorescent labelling of vaccine antigens Attempts to monitor the cellular uptake of antigens in vaccine formulations have frequently made use of commercially available fluorochromes or conjugated immunolabels for detection via fluorescence [ [168](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR168)] and electron microscopy [ [169](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR169)], respectively. While such labels are readily detectable under the respective imaging modalities [ [170](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR170)], whether or not they remain co-localised to their target antigen is less well-established. Such limitations are further compounded when tracing vaccine antigens in complex physiological environments, mimicking those conditions encountered in vivo. Furthermore, the inevitable alterations to the physiochemical properties of the antigen and its co-adsorbed antigen would likely affect the mechanisms by which their cellular uptake subsequently ensues [ [7](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR7), [64](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR64), [89](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR89)]. Recently, the use of direct-fluorescent labelling has allowed for the conformation and intracellular fate of a model amyloid-42 (A42) peptide antigen to be followed in a cellular-based model of vaccination [ [163](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR163)]. Therein, simulated vaccines were prepared adjuvanted with lumogallion-labelled ABAs that were subsequently co-cultured with THP-1 cells. The longer amino acid variant of amyloid, A42, has frequently been implemented in the aetiology of Alzheimer's disease, depositing in brain tissue as extracellular senile plaques, in a -sheet rich conformation [ [171](#ref-CR171), [172](#ref-CR172), [173](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR173)]. These aberrant are suggested to break down into neurotoxic oligomeric A species, triggering a progressive cascade of deleterious effects [ [171](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR171)]. Thioflavin T (ThT) binds to mature amyloid fibrils in a -pleated sheet conformation that thereby allowed for the detection and intracellular fate of the antigen to be assessed [ [163](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR163)]. This new approach to directly label the moiety of interest suggests that A42 is endocytosed by THP-1 cells through micropinocytosis [ co-formulated ABA (Alhydrogel®, Adju-Phos® or Imject® Alum) is processed via alternative pathway of autophagy into late-stage autolysosomes [ [163](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR163)]. The ability of A to evade or disrupt lysosomal capture has recently been implicated in separate studies in both monocytic [ [175](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR175)] and neuronal cell lines [ [168](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR168), [174](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR174)]. The amyloidogenic protein alpha ()-synuclein that forms intraneuronal inclusion or Lewy bodies in Parkinson's disease have also been found to disrupt the formation of autolysosomes [ [176](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR176)]. Therefore, the ability of amyloidogenic proteins to evade lysosomal capture may explain their in [168](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR168), [174](#ref-CR174), [175](#ref-CR175), [176](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR176)]. Furthermore, controlled has been shown to activate the NALP-3 inflammasome and hence such mechanistic modes of action may underlie the immunogenicity of vaccine components [ [177](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR177), [178](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR178)]. Taken collectively, these studies highlight the importance of monitoring the cellular fate of both the antigen and adjuvant constituents of a vaccine in understanding the resultant immune response in vivo [ [163](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR163)]. In conclusion, these approaches may greatly benefit current and future clinical trials utilising immunotherapy for the eradication of neurodegenerative diseases and other complex disease states [ [179](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR179)]. Conclusion Human exposure to aluminium is burgeoning [ [180](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR180)] with significant implications for human health [ [166](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR166), [181](/articles/10.1186/s13223-018-0305-2#ref-CR181)]. ABAs are effective and cheap but are they safe? Confirmation of their safety remains to be addressed and will only come from further research on their biological activities at injection sites and beyond. All ABAs currently in use in vaccination and sub-cutaneous immunotherapy require further validation of their safety, which means that the manufacturer of AAHS should release this ABA so that its safety can be verified independently. Burgeoning knowledge regarding the biological activities of ABAs now dictates that their safety should be evaluated independently of their presence in vaccine formulations.
